There was controversy surrounding the scientific accuracy of The Day After's depiction of the aftermath of a nuclear war. Some experts and scientists criticized the film for exaggerating the extent of destruction and the effects of radiation. They argued that the film failed to accurately portray the complex effects of a nuclear war and misrepresented the potential for survival and recovery after such an event.

One of the main criticisms of the film was that it overestimated the number of casualties that would result from a nuclear war. Critics also claimed that the film underestimated the effects of nuclear winter and the potential for systemic collapse. Some experts argued that the film ignored the potential for sheltering and recovery after a nuclear war and that it exaggerated the speed and completeness of societal collapse.

Despite these criticisms, it is worth noting that The Day After was intended to be a powerful warning about the dangers of nuclear war. While the film's depiction of the aftermath of a nuclear war may not have been scientifically accurate in every detail, it was effective in conveying the devastating consequences that such a war could have on society and human life. Ultimately, the film's impact on public awareness and debate about nuclear weapons and disarmament was significant and enduring.
